concept.title: Phrases and keywords
concept.shortdesc: You can intermix markup with text when you need to identify part of a paragraph or even part of a sentence as having special significance. Phrases can usually contain other phrases and keywords as well as text. Keywords can only contain text.

conbody.p:
There are a lot of phrase-level elements to choose from. It helps to think of them in terms of categories. Generic When you need to assign ids for content reuse, or metadata attributes for flagging and filtering, but don't want to imply anything about the content, you can use markup like <term>, <ph> (phrase), or <keyword>
Software When you need to talk about basic software subjects, use markup like <filepath> (files and paths to files), <cmdname> (command names), and <userinput>.
Programming When you are documenting programming information, use markup like <apiname> (for example a class or method name) or <synph> (a formal syntax description).
User interfaces When you are documenting user interfaces, use markup like <uicontrol> (for example a button or field name) or <wintitle> (a window or dialog name).
Highlighting When you need to draw attention to some content but none of the above categories applies, use one of the highlighting elements, like <b> (bold), <i> (italic), or <tt> (monospace). This is better than using the wrong markup, like applying <codeph> to an email address to get monospace formatting, but not as good as using the right markup if it's available. If you don't like the way the right markup is formatted, talk to your editors or team leads and see if you can get it changed globally, to keep things consistent. Do not misuse markup to get formatting effects: even if the result works within your information set, it may be jarringly inconsistent when your set is combined with others for publication, and have consequences for search rankings and future indexing applications.
